description:
Corynebacterium hesseae is a species of Gram-positive, non-spore-forming, aerobic bacterium that belongs to the genus Corynebacterium. It was first isolated from the skin of a human patient in Germany and was named after the German microbiologist Hans Hesse.

Corynebacterium hesseae is a coryneform bacterium, meaning it has a characteristic club-shaped or palisade arrangement of cells. It is catalase-positive and can grow on various nutrient-rich media, forming small, yellowish-white colonies.

Phylogenetically, Corynebacterium hesseae is closely related to other Corynebacterium species, such as Corynebacterium amycolatum and Corynebacterium glucuronolyticum, which are also commonly found on human skin and mucous membranes.

While Corynebacterium hesseae is considered a commensal organism, meaning it can reside on the human body without causing harm, it has been occasionally associated with opportunistic infections in immunocompromised individuals. Further research is needed to fully understand its clinical significance and potential pathogenic role.
